> <@etportis:matrix.org> Step 4.7. here https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#updating-the-source-set says: 
> 
> "Parse child's sizes attribute with the fallback width _width_, and let source set's source size be the returned value."
> 
> I don't see _width_ defined anywhere, or fallback width used anywhere in the "Parse a sizes attribute" algorithm.
> 
> Ten bucks says I'm just missing something, though. cc: zcorpan

Looks like fallout from https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/5900 -- interested in submitting a PR? :)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @etportis:matrix.org

Step 4.7. here https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#updating-the-source-set says:

"Parse child's sizes attribute with the fallback width width, and let source set's source size be the returned value."

I don't see width defined anywhere, or fallback width used anywhere in the "Parse a sizes attribute" algorithm.

Ten bucks says I'm just missing something, though. cc: zcorpan

Looks like fallout from https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/5900 -- interested in submitting a PR? :)

content.body: anybody know why CSS `background-clip: text` has not been added/upstreamed to https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds/#background-clip
content.formatted_body: anybody know why CSS background-clip: text has not been added/upstreamed to https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds/#background-clip

content.body: and UAs apparently support that for `background-clip`
content.formatted_body: and UAs apparently support that for background-clip

content.body: …but https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds/#background-clip only allows `<box>#`, which resolves to ` border-box | padding-box | content-box` — while the compat spec allows `border-box | padding-box | content-box | text`
content.formatted_body: …but https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds/#background-clip only allows <box>#, which resolves to border-box | padding-box | content-box — while the compat spec allows border-box | padding-box | content-box | text

content.body: further in that case, I wonder in general how much a great idea it is for non-CSS specs to be defining CSS features to begin with

because in that case, the Compat spec is basically patching something in the Pointer Events spec, which is defining something that instead rightly ought to be defined in whatever appropriate a CSS spec
